abstract.para: This guide describes how to use &productname; to update &rhel; &productnumber;.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: &productname; is a technology and support solution for mixed Linux environments. With a &productname; subscription, you can register and receive updates for &rhel; and &sles;. An optional &ha; extension is also available.
You can register &rhla; &productnumber; with one of the following tools:

listitem.para: &rmtool; (&rmt;) on &sle; 15
&suma;

section.para: This guide describes how to register with &rmt; on &sle; 15. &rmt; is a proxy system for the &scc;. The &rmt; server is registered with the &scc;, and other systems in the network are registered with the &rmt; server and receive packages from it directly.

listitem.para: . Make sure you have everything required for the following procedures.
. This server must be installed on &sles; 15. You can skip this step if you already have an &rmt; server in your network.
. You can skip this step if &productname; is already enabled and mirrored on your &rmt; server.
. &rmt; includes a setup script to automate the registration process.

listitem.para: You have a &productname; subscription.
You have a &scc; account.
The systems you want to register are up to date. &productname; only supports the latest minor release of each &rhla; version.

&sles; (&slsa;) 15 is installed and up to date. This machine will be the &rmt; server. You can use the &productname; subscription to register &slsa;. To install &slsa; 15, see
&instquick;.
The systems you want to register can reach the &rmt; server.

The &rmt; server has enough storage available for repository mirroring. Downloaded packages are stored in /usr/share/rmt/public/repo, which is a symbolic link to /var/lib/rmt/public/repo/. The amount of storage required depends on the number of repositories you mirror. We recommend at least 1.5 times the total size of all enabled repositories. Be aware that these repositories will grow substantially over time.

varlistentry.term: nginx.service is inactive after installing the rmt-server package

listitem.para: Continue the procedure to configure &rmt; in &yast;. This often resolves the issue. If that fails, Apache might be installed on your server, and must be disabled. Apache conflicts with NGINX because both web servers listen on port 80.

varlistentry.term: &productname; doesn't appear in rmt-cli products list after rmt-cli sync

listitem.para: Check your network. If the network is down, rmt-cli sync fails without showing an error.
If some packages could not be downloaded because of timeouts, rerun the rmt-cli mirror command until all packages are downloaded.

varlistentry.term: Setup script cannot access the &productname; repository

listitem.para: The repodata directory on the &rmt; server will not be available until all of the packages for that repository are downloaded. If some packages could not be downloaded to the &rmt; server because of timeouts during the first mirroring, rerun the rmt-cli mirror command until all packages are downloaded.

varlistentry.term: Setup script cannot install SUSEConnect because of package dependencies

listitem.para: &productname; only supports the latest minor release of &rhla;. If your system is running the latest version and SUSEConnect still has package dependency issues, try the following workaround:
Edit the rmt-client-setup-res script to add --skip-broken to the following line:
Run the script and accept any proposed package changes. SUSEConnect will be skipped.
Run the script a second time. The package changes from the first attempt can sometimes resolve the package dependency issues, allowing the second attempt to successfully install SUSEConnect.
